question:
Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A one-day-old male is evaluated in the hospital nursery for bilious vomiting. The patient has urinated multiple times since birth but has not yet passed meconium. He was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 36-year-old gravida 3 via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes. The patientвЂ™s mother received routine prenatal care and declined first trimester screening. She subsequently underwent a quadruple screen at 15 weeks gestation that demonstrated decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), increased beta-hCG, decreased unconjugated estriol, and increased inhibin A. Her last ultrasound prior to onset of labor demonstrated an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm. The patientвЂ™s two older siblings are both healthy. The patientвЂ™s temperature is 97.8В°F (36.6В°C), blood pressure is 58/37 mmHg, pulse is 166/min, and respirations are 38/min. On physical exam, the patient is in moderate distress. His abdomen is firm and distended with hypoactive bowel sounds.

What is the most likely etiology of this fetusвЂ™s presentation?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: A one-day-old male born at 38 weeks’ gestation to a 36-year-old gravida 3 via vaginal delivery after a pregnancy complicated by gestational diabetes was evaluated for bilious vomiting, multiple urinary voids since birth without passage of meconium, and a firm, distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds; vital signs were notable for temperature 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure 58/37 mmHg, pulse 166/min, and respirations 38/min, and two older siblings were healthy. The mother declined first trimester screening but underwent a quadruple screen at 15 weeks’ gestation that demonstrated decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), increased beta-hCG, decreased unconjugated estriol, and increased inhibin A, and her last ultrasound prior to the onset of labor reported an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm. The neonatal presentation is consistent with an intestinal obstruction; while Hirschsprung disease—characterized by aganglionosis of a distal colonic segment (most commonly the rectosigmoid) and classically associated with failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours—was considered, the prenatal screening pattern strongly suggests trisomy 21, in which duodenal atresia is a well-recognized gastrointestinal complication due to incomplete luminal recanalization and results in proximal small bowel obstruction manifesting as early bilious emesis and abdominal distension. Taken together, the bilious vomiting with absent meconium, the physical findings of a distended, hypoactive abdomen, and the prenatal markers indicative of Down syndrome with polyhydramnios (AFI 28 cm) strongly support an upper intestinal obstructive lesion at the level of the duodenum, and the most likely etiology is Duodenal atresia.
content.source_2: This one-day-old male neonate, born at 38 weeks’ gestation to a 36-year-old gravida 3 via vaginal delivery, presents with bilious vomiting, multiple urinations without meconium passage, and a firm, distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds; his temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure 58/37 mmHg, pulse 166/min, and respirations 38/min, and his two older siblings are healthy. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes, first trimester screening was declined, and the maternal quadruple screen at 15 weeks demonstrated decreased maternal serum AFP, increased beta-hCG, decreased unconjugated estriol, and increased inhibin A; the last prenatal ultrasound reported an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm, consistent with polyhydramnios, which can be seen when fetal gastrointestinal obstruction impairs normal swallowing and fluid absorption. The constellation of early bilious emesis, failure to pass meconium within the first day, and abdominal distension is most consistent with a mechanical obstruction of the intestinal lumen; although Hirschsprung’s disease is a consideration, the assertion that Hirschsprung’s disease typically would not prevent the passage of meconium in the first day reduces its likelihood in this context, thereby favoring a congenital atretic process characterized by absence or occlusion of an intestinal segment that precludes normal transit of bowel contents. Integrating the clinical presentation and prenatal findings, the most likely etiology is Intestinal atresia.
content.source_3: In a Bayesian framework applied to this case—a one-day-old male neonate born at 38 weeks’ gestation to a 36-year-old gravida 3 via vaginal delivery, with bilious vomiting, no meconium passage despite multiple urinations, and a firm, distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds; vital signs including temperature 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure 58/37 mmHg, pulse 166/min, and respirations 38/min; and two healthy older siblings—the initial differential for neonatal intestinal obstruction includes Hirschsprung’s disease, meconium ileus, and intestinal atresia. The pregnancy history provides critical prior information: gestational diabetes, declined first trimester screening, a 15-week quadruple screen demonstrating decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), increased beta-hCG, decreased unconjugated estriol, and increased inhibin A, and a last prenatal ultrasound with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm. Sequential incorporation of evidence increases the posterior probability of mechanical obstruction: bilious emesis and absent meconium favor an obstructive lesion; abdominal distension with hypoactive bowel sounds and moderate distress further support luminal blockage; and the maternal serum analyte pattern is indicative of Down syndrome, which amplifies the likelihood of congenital gastrointestinal anomalies, notably duodenal atresia, more than aganglionosis. Under this probabilistic synthesis, the convergence of clinical and prenatal data most strongly supports Duodenal atresia in Down Syndrome.
